distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have assumed this because the poet is describing the passions of the sculptor, but loyalty is not what the reference to the word “passions” means.
You may have concluded this because the poet is describing the determination of the sculptor in creating this piece, but determination is not what the reference to the word “passions” means.
You may have thought this because the sculptor put so much effort and care into the making of this sculpture, but love is not what the reference to the word “passions” means.
The reference to the word “passions” in line six refers to the sculptor’s feelings of contempt.
You may have reasoned this because the sculptor must have been inspired to create this piece, but inspiration is not what the reference to the word “passions” means.

questions.stimulus: The tone of the inscription quoted in lines 10-11 is best described as

topics.primary: determine the author's attitude and tone

distractor_rationale_response_level: The tone of lines 10-11 is haughty. Ozymandias is saying look at the mighty creation I’ve created.
You may have assumed this because Ozymandias is telling you to look carefully at what he has created, but he is not being introspective.
You may have concluded this because Ozymandias is telling the observer to despair, but he is not being irate.
You may have misinterpreted this because Ozymandias says “ye Mighty, and despair!”, but he is not being apologetic.
You may have reasoned this because Ozymandias is telling the observer to despair, but he is not being cautious.

questions.stimulus: The poem implies that Ozymandias' "Works" (line 11)

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have assumed this because Ozymandias tells the observer that his words are “Mighty”, but there is no evidence in the poem to suggest that his works were ridiculed by his followers.
You may have concluded this because Ozymandias boasts of his “Mighty” works, but there is no evidence in the poem to suggest that his works continue to attract travelers.
The poem implies that Ozymandias’ “Works” have vanished without a trace. What was once great and mighty have vanished.
You may have thought this because Ozymandias works were so powerful, but there is no evidence in the poem to suggest that these works influenced later architecture.
You may have reasoned this because Ozymandias is boastful and thinks so highly of his accomplishments, but there is no evidence in the poem to suggest that he caused his own downfall.

questions.stimulus: The poem ends on a note of

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have assumed this because nothing is left of the mighty works of Ozymandias, but the poem does not end on a note of regret.
You may have concluded this because the poet says the sands stretch far and away, but the poem does not end on a note of optimism.
You may have thought this because the poet speaks of the vastness of the sands, but the poem does not end on a note of triumph.
The poem ends on a note of irony. Ozymandias boasts of such great works only to have them disappear from view.
You may have reasoned this because Ozymandias tells the observer to look at his great works, but the poem does not end on a note of envy as there is nothing left of his works.

The given rate of 400 sheets every 5 minutes is equivalent to 4,800 sheets every hour. At that rate, 9,600 sheets can be printed in 2 hours and 14,400 sheets in 3 hours. Since 11,000 is between 9,600 and 14,400, the time to print 11,000 sheets will be between 2 and 3 hours.
You may have started writing equivalent rates to 400 sheets every 5 minutes and mistakenly stopped at 3,200 every 40 minutes but treated this as 3,200 every hour.
You may have tried to write equivalent rates to 400 sheets every 5 minutes and found out that 2,400 sheets can be printed out in half an hour (30 minutes) but treated this as 2,400 sheets every hour.

options.label: It cannot be determined from the information given.

questions.stimulus: If \(x+y=4\), what must be the value of \(x^2+y^2\)?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have thought x and y had the same value, 2, and only solved for x or y.
You may have thought x and y had the same value, 2, and computed \(2^2+2^2=4+4=8\).
You may have thought x and y had the same value, 2, and computed \(\left(2+2\right)^2=4^2=16\).
You may have thought x and y both equal 4 and computed \(4^2+4^2=16+16=32\).
The value of x and y cannot be determined from the single given equation \(x+y=4\). Therefore, the value of \(x^2+y^2\) cannot be determined from the information given.

questions.stimulus: Evaluate \(9x-4y-3z^2\) when \(x=\frac{2}{3},\ y=\frac{3}{4},\) and \(z=\sqrt{2}\)

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have subtracted \(\left(3\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) instead of \(3\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) and calculated \(9x-4y-3z^2=9\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-4\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)-\left(3\sqrt{2}\right)^2=6-3-18=-15\).
You may have calculated \(\left(2\right)^2\) instead of \(\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) and calculated \(9x-4y-3z^2=9\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-4\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)-3\left(2\right)^2=6-3-12=-9\).
You correctly substituted the values into the expression and calculated \(9x-4y-3z^2=9\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-4\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)-3\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2=6-3-6=-3\).

You may have calculated \(\left(2\right)^2\) instead of \(\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) and calculated \(9x-4y-3z^2=9\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-4\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)-3\left(2\right)^2=6-3-12=6-15\). But in the end you subtracted 15 – 6 instead of 6 – 15.

You may have added \(\left(3\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) instead of subtracting \(3\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2\) and calculated \(9x-4y+3z^2=9\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-4\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)+\left(3\sqrt{2}\right)^2=6-3+18=21\).

questions.stimulus: Of the following, \(48.912\times\left(38.7+61.4\right)\) is closest to

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have rounded each value to the closest ten but calculated 50(40 + 60) = 50(100) as 50,000 instead of 5,000.
Each of the given values is close to a ten and rounding each to its closest ten yields the approximation 50(40 + 60) = 50(100) = 5,000.
You may have incorrectly rounded 38.7 to 30 instead of 40 and calculated 50(30 + 60) = 50(90) = 4,500.
You may have incorrectly rounded 48.912 to 40 instead of 50 and calculated 40(40 + 60) = 40(100) = 4,000.
You may have incorrectly rounded each value down instead of rounding to the closest ten and calculated 40(30 + 60) = 40(90) = 3,600. And 3,500 is the closes answer choice to 3,600.

questions.stimulus: In the triangle, \(x=\)

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have solved the equation \(60+3x=180\) by adding 60 to 180 instead of subtracting.
You may have solve \(3x=150\) instead of \(3x=120\).
You may have solved \(60+2x\ =150\) instead of \(60+2x+x=180\).
Since the sum of the three angle measures of any triangle is 180°, \(60+2x+x=180\). This can be simplified as \(60+3x=180\), The solution of this equation is 40.
You may have solved \(60+2x+2x\) instead of \(60+2x+x=180\).

questions.stimulus: If \(n\) is a positive integer greater than 2, then the value of which of the following CANNOT be an integer?

distractor_rationale_response_level: Unless n is has a value of 1 or 2, it cannot divide evenly into a number that is 2 greater than n. So, the given expression cannot have an integer value if n is greater than 2.
You may have overlooked that every possible value of \(6n+8\) when n is an integer greater than 2 is an even number. So, half the value of that expression will be an integer as well.
You may have overlooked that the value of \(5-n\) is be an integer for any integer value of n.
You may have overlooked that any number that is 4 less than an integer is also an integer.
You may have overlooked that any number that is 3 times an integer is also an integer, and that any number that is 10 less than an integer is also an integer.

questions.stimulus: Sam had to read 60 pages a day to finish an assignment on time, but he read an extra 5 pages a day. As a result, for the last 4 days he had only 135 pages left to read. How many days in all did Sam have to finish the assignment?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have divided the planned number of days, 60, by 5, but but that does not represent the relationship between Sam's original planned reading pace and his actual pace, which left 135 pages remaining with four days to go.
You may have solved \(5x=135-60\), but that does not represent the relationship between Sam's original planned reading pace and his actual pace, which left 135 pages remaining with four days to go.

Let the expression \(60x\) represent the total number of pages in the assignment, where x is the number of days given to complete at a rate of 60 pages per day. Sam read 65 pages for \(x-4\) days and had 135 pages left. So, the equation \(60x=65\left(x-4\right)+135\) represents this situation. Simplifying the right side of that equation results in \(60x=65x-125\). The solution of that equation is 25, and so Sam had 25 days to finish the assignment.
You solved the equation \(60x=65x+135\), but that equation does not account for the four days Sam had left when he had 135 pages remaining.
You may have solved \(5x=135+60\), but that does not represent the relationship between Sam's original planned reading pace and his actual pace, which left 135 pages remaining with four days to go.

questions.stimulus: Point \(G\) bisects the line segment \(\overline{FH}\). The length of \(\overline{FG}\) is 32 less than 3 times the length of \(\overline{GH}\). What is the length of \(\overline{FG}\)?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have solved \(x=3x-32\) by adding \(x\)  to \(3x\) instead of subtracting.
Since the two line segments are equal in length, the equation \(x=3x-32\) represents the given relationship. The solution of the equation is 16.
You maybe have taken 18 to be the solution of \(2x=32\), but 16 is half of 32.
You may have represented the relationship with \(x=3\left(x-32\right)\) instead of \(x=3x-32\).
You may have multiplied 32 instead of dividing when solving \(2x=32\).

questions.stimulus:
A spherical balloon has a volume of 36\(\pi\) cubic inches. What is the radius, in inches, of the balloon?

\(\left(V=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\right)\)

distractor_rationale_response_level: Given the volume formula, \(V=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\), and the balloon volume of \(36\pi\) cubic inches, the radius is the solution of \(36\pi=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\). Dividing both sides of that equation by \(\frac{4}{3}\pi\) results in \(r^3=27\). So, the value of r is the cube root of 27, 3.
You may have divided 27 by 3 instead of taking its cube root when solving \(r^3=27\).
You may have overlooked the need to take the cube root of the value of \(r^3\) when solving \(36\pi=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\).
You may have multiplied 36 by \(\frac{4}{3}\) instead of dividing when solving \(36\pi=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\), and overlooked the need to take the cube root of the value of \(r^3\).
You may have tripled 27 instead of taking its cube root when solving \(r^3=27\).

questions.stimulus: In the multiplication problem \(\square4\times\triangle6\), the symbols \(\square\) and \(\triangle\) represent digits. Which of the following could be the product?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have overlooked that no two-digit factors of 100 have 4 or 6 in the ones place.
You may have overlooked that at least one of the factors of a three-digit number that is a multiple of 10 must have 0 or 5 in the ones place.
Since the product of 4 and 6 is 24, the digit in the ones place when two whole numbers ending in 4 and 6, respectively, are multiplied must be 4.
You may have overlooked that at least one of the factors of a three-digit with 6 in the ones place must have factors that with the digits 1 and 6, 2 and 3, 2 and 8, or 4 and 4 in the ones places.
You may have overlooked that at least one of the factors of a four-digit with 6 in the ones place must have factors that with the digits 1 and 6, 2 and 3, 2 and 8, or 4 and 4 in the ones places.

questions.stimulus: A family of five- two parents and three children- are hiking. They come to a narrow path where they must walk in a single file line. They decide to walk with a parent at the beginning of the line, a parent at the end of the line, and the children in the middle. How many different ways can the family arrange themselves in such a line?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have calculated the number of possible orderings by raising 2 (the number of ways to order the parent) by the power of the number of children, but 2 should be multiplied by 3! (the product of a 3, 2, and 1), as that is the number of ways the three children can be ordered.
Given these conditions, there are two ways to order the parents and six ways to order the children (the product of 3, 2, and 1). So the total number of orderings is the product of 6 and 2.
You may have multiplied that number of ways to order the children, 6, by 4, but there are only two ways to order the parents.

You may have have multiplied the square of the number of parents by the cube of the number of children, but he total number of orderings is the product of 6 (the number of ways to order the children) and 2 (the number of ways to order the parents).

You calculated the number of ways of ordering five people when there are no restrictions, but the condition that the parents must be first and last in line means that there are fewer possible orderings.

questions.stimulus: Evaluate: \(-16+2\left(4-\left(6-8\right)^2\right)\)

topics.secondary: basic concepts of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division

distractor_rationale_response_level: Following the rules for order of operations, the operations inside parentheses should be performed first. So,  \(-16+2\left(4-\left(6-8\right)^2\right)=-16+2\left(4-\left(-2\right)^2\right)\), and \(-16+2\left(4-\left(-2\right)^2\right)=-16+2\left(4-4\right)\). Since \(4-4=0\), \(-16+2\left(4-4\right)\ =\ -16+2\left(0\right)\), and \(-16+2\left(0\right)=-16\).
You may have overlooked the exponent in the expression.
You may have multiplied \(-16+2\) by zero, but \(-16+2\left(0\right)=-16+0\).
You may have squared \(4-\left(6-8\right)\) instead of \(6-8\).
You may have squared \(4-6-8\) instead of \(6-8\).

questions.stimulus: There are a total of 19 boys and 14 girls in Fernando's class. The names of each of Fernando's classmates are written on individual slips of paper and placed in a box. Fernando is to select a project partner by drawing the name of one classmate from the box. What are the chances that he will draw a boy's name?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You identified that ratio of the number of selections to the number of possible desired outcomes, but the probability of selecting a boy is the ratio of the number of desired outcomes (the number of boy classmates) to the total number of possible outcomes (the total number of classmates).

You identified that ratio of the number of selections to the number of boys in the class, but the probability of selecting a boy is the ratio of the number of desired outcomes (the number of boy classmates) to the total number of possible outcomes (the total number of classmates).

You identified that ratio of the number of selections to the number of possible desired outcomes, but the probability of selecting a boy is the ratio of the number of desired outcomes (the number of boy classmates) to the total number of possible outcomes (the total number of classmates).
Fernando has 18 classmates who are boys (he is the nineteenth boy in the class) and 14 classmates who are girls. As there a total of 32 classmates, the probability of selecting a boy is 18 in 32.
You may have overlooked that since Fernando is one of the 19 boys, he is not one of the classmates he could select from.

questions.stimulus: If \(x\) and \(y\) are positive numbers, \(\frac{x^8}{y^2}=180\) and \(x^6=5\), what is the value of \(\frac{x}{y}\)?

distractor_rationale_response_level: You may have divided in the opposite direction when combining \(\frac{x^8}{y^2}\) and \(x^6\), and then used the result as the value of \(\frac{x^2}{y^2}\), rather than its square root.
You may have divided in the opposite direction when combining \(\frac{x^8}{y^2}\) and \(x^6\).

Since \(\frac{x^8}{y^2}=180\) and \(x^6=5\), \(\frac{x^2}{y^2}=36\). This is because \(\frac{x^8}{x^6y^2}=\frac{180}{5}\) , and \(\frac{x^8}{x^6y^2}=\frac{x^2}{y^2}\). The square of root \(\frac{x^2}{y^2}\) of  is \(\frac{x}{y}\), and the square root of 36, the value of \(\frac{180}{5}\), is 6.
You may have taken 30 instead of 36 be the result of dividing 180 by 5, and then used the result as the value of \(\frac{x^2}{y^2}\), rather than its square root.
You found the value of \(\frac{x^2}{y^2}\), but \(\frac{x}{y}\) is the square root of that expression.

features.content:
In 1742, at the age of 14, James Cook went, or ran away, to sea, shipping at Whitby on board the Freelove, a collier belonging to the brothers Walker. In this hard school Cook learnt his sailor duties. No better training could have been found for his future responsibilities. Here he learnt to endure the utmost rigours of the sea. Constant fighting with North Sea gales, bad food, and cramped accommodation, taught him to regard with the indifference that afterwards distinguished him, all the hardships that he had to encounter, and led him to endure and persevere where others, less determined or more easily daunted by difficulties, would have hurried on, and left their work incomplete.

Few sailed for the purpose of exploration pure and simple; and even those who started with that view found, when embarked on that vast expanse, that prudence dictated that they should have a moderate certainty of, by a certain time, falling in with a place of sure refreshment. The provisions they carried were bad at starting, and by the time they had fought their way through the Straights of Magellan were already worse; water was limited, and would not hold out more than a given number of days. Every voyage that is pursued tells the same story - short of water, and eagerly looking out for an opportunity of replenishing it.

Becoming Americans did not mean scrubbing away our heritage. The teachers, trying as best they could to sound the Japanese or Italian pronunciation, called us by the names of our parents used. None of us ever suffered for speaking our native languages. Matti told the class about his mother's down quilt, which she had made in Italy. Encarnacion acted out how boys learned to fish in the Philippines. I astounded the class with the story of my travels on a stagecoach, which my classmates had seen only in museums. Miss Hopley herself would express openly her wonder about these matters. For me, becoming an American did not mean forgetting that I was also Mexican.

Getting to be an American, however, was not an entirely smooth matter. I had to fight one lout who doubled up with laughter over one of my translations until I straightened him out with a kick. But it was Homer who gave me the most lasting lesson for a future American.

Home was an Irishman who dressed as if every day were Sunday. And Homer was smart, as he clearly showed when he and I ran for president of the third grade. Everyone understood that this would be a demonstration of how the American people vote for president. In an election, Miss Hopley explained, the candidates could be generous and vote for each other. We cast our ballots and Homer won by two votes. I polled my supporters and concluded that I had voted for Homer and so had he. He didn't deny it, reminding me that the teacher had said he could vote for each other but didn't have to.

Mostly the captain would not speak when spoken to, only look up sudden and fierce and blow through his nose like a fog-horn; and we and people who came about our house soon learned to let him be. Every day when he came back from his stroll, he would ask if any seafaring men had gone by along the road. At first we thought it was the want of company of his own kind that made him ask this question, but at last we began to see he was desirous to avoid them. When a seaman did put up at the Admiral Benbow (as now and then some did, making by the coast road for Bristol) he would look in at him through the curtained door before he entered the parlour; and he was always sure to be as silent as a mouse when any such was present.

Sir Arthur Conan Doyle said that his character of Sherlock Holmes was inspired by Dr. Joseph Bell, for whom Doyle had worked as a clerk. Like Holmes, Bell was noted for drawing large conclusions from the smallest observations. Sir Henry Littlejohn is also considered a source for Holmes. Littlejohn served as a police surgeon and medical officer, providing for Doyle a link between medical investigation and the detection of crime.

The primary intellectual detection method used by Holmes is abductive reasoning. "From a drop of water," a logician could detect "the possibility of an Atlantic or a Niagara without having seen or heard of one or the other." Holmes' stories often begin with a bravura display of his talent. "Holmesian" detection often appears to consist of drawing conclusions based on straightforward practice principles that are the result of careful observation, such as Holmes' study of different kinds of cigar ashes. One quote often used by Holmes is, "When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth."

In "A Scandal in Bohemia," Holmes deduces that his friend Dr. Watson had got very wet lately and that he had "a most clumsy and careless servant girl." When Watson asks how Holmes knows this, Holmes answers: "It is simplicity itself. My eyes tell me that on the inside of your left shoe, just where the firelight strikes it, the leather is scored by six almost parallel cuts. Obviously they have been caused by someone who has very carelessly scraped round the edges of the sole in order to remove crusted mud from it. Hence, it is plain to see that you had been out in vile weather."

As is so often the case, Watson is amazed.

Around the world, deaf individuals have long used hang gestures to communicate. In 1775, a church leader in France developed a system of finger spelling. One hand gesture stood for each letter in the alphabet. This allowed deaf users of sign language to spell out words by forming shapes with their hands. Americans were introduced to sign language in the early 1800s, when Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet, a minister, traveled to Europe in search of a way to help his neighbor's deaf child learn to communicate. In Europe, Gallaudet learned about the French system of sign language and began adapting it for Americans. Upon his return to the United States, he started the first school for the deaf in the country. Over time, Gallaudet's system became what we know now as American Sign Language, or ASL.

Sign languages vary across the world, and most cultures have a system of signing. Although they do not use spoken words, sign languages are otherwise much like any other language. Rules of grammar govern the language's use. For instance, in an English sentence, the subject typically goes before the verb. In ASL, however, the order of gestures can vary. In spoken languages, a speaker can use his or her tone of voice to communicate different emotions, but sign languages rely on other tools, such as facial expressions, to accomplish this. For instance, signers can change the statement "You are hungry" to the question "Are you hungry?" by changing their body language (for instance, by leaning forward) and using their eyebrows. 

Over the past two centuries, ASL has grown and become more complex as more people have learned it. Schools for deaf students, including a university name for Thomas Gallaudet, have been established. American Sign Language is now the fourth most common language used in the United States.

During these days of preparation, Queequeg and I often visited the craft, and as often I asked about Captain Ahab and how he was and when he was going to come on board his ship. To these questions they would answer that he was getting better and better and was expected aboard every day; meantime the two Captains, Peleg and Bildad, could attend to everything necessary to fit the vessel for the voyage. If I had been downright honest with myself, I would have seen very plainly in my heart that I did but half fancy being committed this way to so long a voyage, without once laying my eyes on the man who was to be the absolute dictator of it so soon as the ship sailed out upon the open sea. But when a man suspects any wrong, it sometimes happens that if he be already involved in the matter, he insensibly strives to cover up his suspicions even from himself. And much this way it was with me. I said nothing, and I tried to think of nothing.

It is the strangest yellow, that wallpaper! It makes me think of all the yellow things I ever saw—not beautiful ones like buttercups, but old foul, bad yellow things.

But there is something else about that paper—the smell! I noticed it the moment we came into the room, but with so much air and sun it was not bad. Now we have had a week of fog and rain, and whether the windows are open or not, the smell is here.

It creeps all over the house.

I find it hovering in the dining-room, skulking in the parlor, hiding in the hall, lying in wait for me on the stairs.

It gets into my hair.

Even when I go to ride, if I turn my head suddenly and surprise it—there is that smell! Such a peculiar odor, too! I have spent hours in trying to analyze it, to find what it smelled like.

It is not bad—at first, and very gentle, but quite the subtlest, most enduring odor I ever met.

In this damp weather it is awful, I wake up in the night and find it hanging over me.

It used to disturb me at first. I thought seriously of burning the house—to reach the smell.

But now I am used to it. The only thing I can think of that it is like is the COLOR of the paper! A yellow smell.

There is a very funny mark on this wall, low down, near the mopboard. A streak that runs round the room. It goes behind every piece of furniture, except the bed, a long, straight, even SMOOCH, as if it had been rubbed over and over.

I wonder how it was done and who did it, and what they did it for. Round and round and round—round and round and round—it makes me dizzy!

I met a traveler from an antique land,

Who said—"Two vast and trunkless legs of stone

Stand in the desert. Near them, on the sand, 

Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown,

And wrinkled lips and sneer of cold command

Tell that its sculptor well those passions read

Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,

The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed; 

And on the pedestal these words appear

'My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings,

Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!'

Nothing beside remains. Round the decay

Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare,

The lone and level sands stretch far away!"
